qas.question: What major event did The Times reluctantly support in the nineteenth century despite being initially opposed?
The Times greatly supported what bill in 1832 which reduced corruption and increased the electorate?
Many demonstrations in the nineteenth century convinced The Times editorial board to finally support the repeal of what laws?
During the American Civil War, what classes of people did The Times support?
The Times favoured which political side of the American Civil War?

context: In other events of the nineteenth century, The Times opposed the repeal of the <a2_0>Corn Laws<a2_0/> until the number of demonstrations convinced the editorial board otherwise, and only reluctantly supported aid to victims of the <a0_0>Irish Potato Famine<a0_0/>. It enthusiastically supported the <a1_0>Great Reform Bill of 1832<a1_0/>, which reduced corruption and increased the electorate from 400,000 people to 800,000 people (still a small minority of the population). During the American Civil War, The Times represented the view of the <a3_0>wealthy classes<a3_0/>, favouring <a4_0>the secessionists<a4_0/>, but it was not a supporter of slavery.
